questions.question: The life cycle given below is of which of the following:CDCSAFER-HEALTHIER PE OPLEMature cystsingested

options.D: E. histolyticaInfective StageDiagnostic StageANoninvasive ColonizationB=Intestinal DiseaseExtraintestinal DiseaseCysts and tophozoitespassed in fecesMultiplicationExcystationTrophozoitesCystsBTrophozoitesExits host

questions.question: A 40-year-old man is diagnosed to have amoebic dysentery. Which of the following is theinfective form of the protozoan causing this disease?
questions.explanation: The mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form of Entamoeba histolytica causing amoebicdysentery. It is passed in feces and can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days.The following are the characteristic features of various life stages of Entamoeba histolytica:The trophozoite is found only in tissues. Its cytoplasm has a ground-glass appearance. Thenucleus has a central karyosome with radiating fibrils called linin network giving a cartwheelappearance. Pseudopodia are present which exhibit gliding motility.The below image shows trophozoite form.518The precystic stage has a large glycogen vacuole and 2 chromatid bars. It secretes a refractile cystwall to become a cyst.The cystic stage has a mature cyst with 4 nuclei and no glycogen mass. Chromatid bars disappear.The below image shows cystic form.

questions.question: 505A 25-year-old woman presented with complaints of abdominal pain and 6 episodes of passingfoul-smelling dark stool mixed with mucus and blood streaks. There is no history of fever andtenesmus. On examination, vitals are stable and localized tenderness is present in the rightiliac fossa. Which of the following is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of amoebic dysentery and the causative agent isEntamoeba histolytica.Clinical features of intestinal amebiasis:• Acute intestinal amebiasis- dysentery, lower abdominal discomfort, and flatulence.519• Chronic amebiasis- low-grade symptoms such as occasional diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue.• The amoebic ulcer which is flask-shaped is the typical lesion seen in intestinal amoebiasis. Theulcers are multiple and are confined to the colon. Sometimes, in secondary intestinal lesions, theulcers are numerous in the cecum, followed by the sigmoido-rectal region.A granulomatous lesion called an ameboma may form in the cecal or rectosigmoid areas of thecolon which can resemble an adenocarcinoma of the colon.The most appropriate treatment is intravenous metronidazole.Option A - Giardia is often asymptomatic, but in some cases can lead to fat malabsorption, dullepigastric pain, and flatulence.-Option C Campylobacter presents with fever, pain, and watery diarrhea. The stool containsleucocytes and blood.Option D - Shigella causes bacillary dysentery which is characterised by fever and generalisedabdominal tenderness.

questions.question: You received a stool sample of a patient suspected to have dysentery in the microbiology lab.On microscopy, you observe the structures shown in the image. What other findings you willexpect to see in this stool sample?

options.A: RBCs as discrete or in rouleaux

questions.explanation: The given image is showing erythrophagocytosis (trophozoite with ingested RBCs) and this in thestool sample of a patient with features of dysentery is indicative of amoebic dysentery. The otherstool microscopic finding seen in amoebic dysentery is Charcot-Leyden crystals.The ingested erythrocytes appear as dark inclusions. Erythrophagocytosis is the onlycharacteristic that can be used to morphologically differentiate E. histolytica from thenonpathogenic entamoeba.Amoebic dysentery:Clinically, it is insidious in onset with localized abdominal tenderness. Tenesmus, toxicity, andfever are absent.Under microscopy, RBCs are clumped, yellowish-brown in color. Charcot-Leyden crystals andeosinophils are present.Charcot-Leyden crystals are diamond-shaped, clear, and refractile structures that may be seen instool specimens under microscopy and represent breakdown products of eosinophils.The below image shows Charcot-Leyden crystals:520

questions.question: A patient with abdominal pain and mucus in stool is diagnosed to have intestinal amoebiasis.Which of the following is the most common extraintestinal complication of this disease?506
questions.explanation: The most common extraintestinal complication of amoebiasis is hepatic amoebiasis.In intestinal amoebiasis, most of the trophozoites reach the liver. However, only a small portion ofthem actually lodge and multiply in the liver cells. Patients usually present with an enlarged,tender liver without detectable impairment of liver function called amoebic hepatitis.Few patients go on to develop amoebic liver abscess. The center of the abscess contains thickchocolate brown pus (anchovy sauce pus), which is made up of liquefied necrotic liver tissue. It isbacteriologically sterile and free of amoeba. The periphery is made up of nearly normal liver tissuecontaining invading amoeba.Complications and sequelae of intestinal amoebiasis:• Fulminant amoebic colitis•Toxic megacolon•Perianal ulceration• Amoeboma• Extraintestinal amoebiasis.• Hepatic amoebiasis (most common)- Amoebic hepatitis and Amoebic liver abscess•Amoebic appendicitis and peritonitis• Pulmonary amoebiasis• Cerebral amoebiasis•Splenic abscess•Cutaneous amoebiasisGenitourinary amoebiasis521Complications of amoebiasisPulmonaryamoebiasisSubdiaphragmaticabscessHepaticamoebiasisAmoebicappendicitisMARROWCerebralamoebiasisAmoeboma

questions.question: A 40-year-old man was brought to the casualty with complaints of nausea, vomiting anddisorientation. His brother tells you they had recently gone on a camping trip where they hadswum in a freshwater lake. On examination, Kernig's sign is positive. A spinal tap isperformed and the findings of CSF wet mount microscopy are shown below. Which of thefollowing is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and microscopy showing amoeboid trophozoite form with pseudopodiais suggestive of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis. It is caused by Naegleria fowleri.It is also known as brain-eating amoeba. It occurs in 3 forms: cyst, amoeboid trophozoite andflagellate trophozoite forms.The infection usually follows swimming in freshwater rivers or ponds. The amoebae invade thenasal mucosa and pass through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into themeninges. Incubation period is 2 days to 2 weeks.Treatment is with intravenous amphotericin B.Options B & D: Both Acanthamoeba and B.mandrillaris cause granulomatous amoebicmeningoencephalitis which is a subacute condition.Option C: A. cantonensis is the most common cause of eosinophilic meningitis in Southeast Asia.It is a nematode(roundworm).

questions.question: A college student presents with ocular redness, foreign body sensation, and corneal ulcersfollowing the use of contact lens. The saline mount preparation of the corneal scraping showspolygonal cysts. What would be the most probable cause?
questions.explanation: The given clinical history and the demonstration of polygonal cysts are suggestive of amoebickeratitis caused by acanthamoeba.Acanthamoeba culbertsoni is a free-living amoeba. It exists as trophozoite form and resistantcystic form. Both these forms are infective. The trophozoite is large and characterized byspine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia).Human beings acquire the infection by inhalation of cysts or trophozoites, ingestion of cysts, ordirectly through traumatized skin or eyes.522It presents as two chronic conditions- acanthamoeba keratitis and granulomatous amoebicencephalitis.Diagnosis of amoebic keratitis is made by the demonstration of the cyst in corneal scrapings bywet mount, histology, and culture.The below image shows the ring lesion seen in acanthamoeba keratitis.DAILYROUNDSThe below image shows cysts of acanthamoeba in lactophenol cotton blue staining.

questions.question: Which of the following protozoan parasites is found in the lumen of the human smallintestine?
questions.explanation: Image 2 shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia, which is the only protozoan parasite found inthe lumen of the human small intestine. It lives in the duodenum and upper jejunum.523Other protozoan parasites found in the human small intestine do not occur in the lumen but arepresent in the epithelial cells lining the small intestine. These include:•⚫ Isospora belli• Cyclospora cayetanensis••Cryptosporidium parvumSarcocystis hominisOptions A and C: Entamoeba histolytica and Balantidium coli are found in the human largeintestine.Option D: Trichomonas vaginalis is found in the genital tract.The image given below shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia.GThe image given below shows the trophozoite of Entamoeba histolytica.524The image given below shows the trophozoite of Balantidium coli.The image given below shows the trophozoite of Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.question: A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhea. Thehistopathology of the ■duodenum is shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?508an B
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with the histopathology showing trophozoites of Giardia lamblia in theduodenal wall is suggestive of giardiasis.Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is the onlycommon pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans.Infection occurs by the ingestion of mature cysts in contaminated water and food andis transmitted by the faeco-oral route.525It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Secretory IgA and IL-6 are responsible for clearing theinfection. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemic, ormalnourished individuals.Clinical features:• Diarrhea• Fat malabsorption• Dull epigastric pain•Belching and flatulence•• Iron deficiency and growth stunting.• Stool will have excess mucus and fat but no blood.Detection of antigen by ELISA is more sensitive and specific than microscopy. Entero test is alsoused in the diagnosis.Histopathology of the duodenum reveals several heart-shaped or pear-shaped trophozoites withtwo equally sized nuclei. The small intestinal morphology is usually normal. However, in heavyinfections, there may be villous blunting and intraepithelial infiltrates.Metronidazole/tinidazole/nitazoxanide are the first-line agents in the treatment.The image given below shows a magnified view of the pear-shaped trophozoites of Giardialamblia.OMARROW

questions.question: A patient is undergoing the test depicted in the image given below. Which of the followingdiseases does it help to diagnose?
questions.explanation: The given image depicts a string test or entero test and is used in the diagnosis of giardiasis.It is a useful method for obtaining the duodenal specimen in giardiasis.526In this test, a coiled thread inside a small weighted gelatin capsule is swallowed by the patient,after attaching the free end of the thread in the cheek. The capsule passes through the stomach tothe duodenum. After 2 hours, the thread is withdrawn, placed in saline, and is shaken. Thecentrifuged deposit of the saline is then examined for giardia.

questions.question: The findings of the microscopic examination of the wet mount preparation of stool of apatient with diarrhoea is shown below. Which of the following organisms will exhibit this typeof motility?
questions.explanation: The given wet mount preparation of stool shows organisms having falling leaf motility. It isexhibited by Giardia lamblia.The trophozoite is motile with a slow oscillation along its long axis resembling a falling leaf.

questions.question: A patient came to the gynecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginaldischarge and intense itching. The per speculum finding is given below. Which of thefollowing statements is false regarding the causative organism of this disease?510

options.A: It exists in cyst and trophozoite form
options.C: The gold standard for diagnosis is culture on CPLM or PEM

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with the image showing strawberry cervix is suggestive of Trichomonasvaginalis infection. It exists only in trophozoite form.Trichomonas vaginalis is the only protozoan with one stage in its life cycle ie., trophozoite form(no cyst stage is seen). It is an obligate parasite and cannot live without close association withvaginal, urethral or prostatic tissues.The common presentation of trichomoniasis is foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge, itching, anddysuria. The gold standard for diagnosis is culture on CPLM (cysteine-peptone-liver-maltose) orPEM (plastic envelope medium). The treatment of choice is metronidazole.T. vaginalis infection in women may lead to infertility, preterm birth and low-birth-weight infants.In men, trichomoniasis has been also associated with infertility through inflammatory damage tothe genitourinary tract or interference with sperm function.The below image shows the trophozoite form of Trichomonas vaginalis.527DAILYROUNDS

questions.question: A 12-year-old child presented to you with fever, malaise, and weight loss. On examination,you notice the finding shown in the image. In which of the following conditions is this seen?
questions.explanation: The given image shows posterior cervical lymphadenopathy which is called Winterbottom's sign.It is seen in West African sleeping sickness.It is seen in stage I of West African sleeping sickness caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense.The table below shows diseases caused by various Trypanosoma species.ProtozoaTrypanosoma brucei gambienseTrypanosoma brucei rhodesienseTrypanosoma cruziDiseaseWest African sleeping sicknesSEast African sleeping sicknesSChagas' disease/South American trypanosomiasis

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding Trypanosoma?

options.A: Tsetse fly is the vector for both T. rhodesiense and T. gambiense
options.D: Humans are the reservoir for T. rhodesiense

questions.explanation: Humans are the reservoir for T. gambiense, not for T. rhodesiense.The table below shows characteristic differences between West African and East Africantrypanosomiasis.Parasites causing myocarditis include:• Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense• Trypanosoma cruzi• Toxoplasma gondii• Echinococcus granulosus••Trichinella spiralisCharacteristicsWest African trypanosomiasisEast African trypanosomiasiSOrganismT. brucei gambienseVectorTsetse flyReservoirHumansCourse of diseasChronicT. brucei rhodesienseTsetse flyWild and domestic animalsAcuteeParasitemiaVirulenceLowLessHighMore528CharacteristicsMortalityWest African trypanosomiasisLowEast African trypanosomiasiSHigh

questions.question: A middle-aged woman presents to the OPD with fever and malaise for the past 4 months. Onexamination, the following ocular finding is noted along with hepatosplenomegaly andlymphadenopathy. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with the image showing Romana's sign is suggestive of Chagas disease.It is caused by T. cruzi. Reduviid bugs are vectors for Chagas disease.Inoculation of T. cruzi in conjunctiva causes unilateral, painless edema of periocular tissues in theeye is called Romana's sign. This is classically seen in acute Chagas disease that lasts for 1 to 4months.The following image shows a patient with Romana's sign.DAILYROUNDSAcute Chagas disease is also characterised by the presence of chagomas which are subcutaneouslesions occurring at the site of inoculation.Chronic Chagas disease is characterized by megaesophagus, megacolon, and myopathy.Shown below is an image of the Reduviid bug.529

questions.question: Which of the following is used for the culture of Trypanosoma?
questions.explanation: NNN (Novy, McNeal, and Nicolle) medium is used for the culture of Trypanosoma brucie andcruzie. It is also used for the culture of Leishmania.The other media used in the culture of Trypanosoma are Weinman's medium and Tobie'smedium.Options B, C & D: Boeck and Drbohlav medium, Craig's medium and NIH polygenic mediumare used for the culture of E.histolytica.

questions.question: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms?Triatomine bug stagesTriatomine bug takes a bloodmeal (passes metacyclictrypomastigotes in feces,trypomastigotes enter bitewound or mucosalmembranes, such as theconjunctiv

options.A: Metacyclictrypomastigotesin hindgut7Multiply in midgut65Epimastigotesin midgutTriatomine bug takes ablood meal (trypomastig-otes ingestedInfective stageDiagnostic stageOMARROWa) Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense
options.D: Trypanosoma rangeliMammalian stagesMetacyclic trypomastigotespenetrate various cells at bitewound site. Inside cells theytransform into amastigotes,Amastigotes multiply bybinary fission in cells ofinfected tissuesTrypomastigotescan infect othercells andtransform intointracellularamastigotes innew infection sitesIntracellular amastigotestransform into trypomastig-otes, then burst out of the celland enter the bloodstream.

questions.explanation: The given life cycle belongs to Trypanosoma cruzi.T. cruzi is the causative organism of Chagas disease or South American trypanosomiasis. They areintracellular parasites.It passes its life cycle in two hosts- the definitive host is the man and the intermediate host(vector) is reduviid bug or triatomine bugs.Metacyclic trypomastigotes are the infective forms to the man that are found in feces of reduviidbugs. Transmission occurs when mucus membranes, conjunctiva, or wound on the surface of theskin are contaminated by feces of the bug.Inside the definitive host, the trypomastigotes differentiate into intracellular amastigotes. Theamastigotes multiply by binary fission and differentiate into trypomastigotes, which are thenreleased into the bloodstream. These are the infective stage for triatomine bug. No multiplicationoccurs in this stage.Inside the triatomine bug, the trypomastigotes are transformed into epimastigotes and theninto metacyclic trypomastigotes in the hindgut which are excreted in feces.530Note: Amastigote forms resemble the Leishmania spp. and hence they are frequently known asLeishmanial forms. They are found in muscular tissue, nervous tissue, and reticuloendothelialsystem.

questions.question: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms?513Sandfly Stages1 Sandfly takes a blood meal(injects promastigote stageinto the skin)Human StagesPromastigotes arephagocytized bymacrophagesor other typesof mononuclearphagocytic cells8Divide in the gut andmigrate to proboscisAmastigotes transform intopromastigote stage in the gutIngestion ofparasitized cell5 Sandfly takes a blood meal(ingests macrophages infectedwith amastigotes)Infective StageDiagnostic Stage

options.D: Babesia microtiPromastigotes transforminto amastigotesAmastigotes multiply in cellsof various tissues and infectother cellsdCD CSAFER HEALTHIER PEOPLE

questions.explanation: The given life cycle belongs to Leishmania donovani.The definitive hosts are man, dog, and other mammals and the vector/intermediate host is femalesandfly. Promastigotes are infective forms to man.•L. donovani exists in 2 forms:Amastigote form- in humans and other mammals• Promastigote form- in the sandfly and artificial cultureWhen the infected sandfly bites a person, infectious promastigotes are released into the hostdermis along with the sandfly saliva, which potentiates parasite infectivity.Amastigote form (as shown in the image below) is also known as Leishman-Donovan (LD) body. Itis an intracellular form found inside macrophages, monocytes and reticuloendothelial cells. Itcontains a kinetoplast which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast. Flagellum isabsent.Promastigote form (as shown in the below image) is present in the midgut of the female sandfly.The kinetoplast lies transversely near the anterior end. A single flagellum is seen. It is theinfective form of Leishmania donovani for humans.531

questions.question: You are performing the following diagnostic procedure in a patient having fever for the past 2weeks to find the causative organism. Which disease are you most likely testing for?
questions.explanation: The given image shows bone marrow aspiration and it is most commonly done to diagnoseKala-azar.The microscopic demonstration of amastigotes from bone marrow is the gold standard for thediagnosis of Kala-azarGenerally, the sternal marrow is aspirated by puncturing the sternum at the level of the 2nd or3rd intercostal space, using a sternal puncture needle.Other samples collected are peripheral blood, splenic aspirate, and enlarged lymph node.In kala-azar:• Most common specimen collected for microscopy- bone marrow aspirate.•• Most sensitive method- splenic aspirate.Option B: Schistosomiasis is typically diagnosed by stool examination for parasite eggs.Option C: Toxoplasmosis is usually diagnosed based on serologic testing.Option D: Chagas disease is diagnosed by peripheral blood smear examination, culture andexamination of aspirates from lymph nodes and chagoma.

questions.question: What is the vector for the condition diagnosed by the image shown below?
questions.explanation: The image shown is of the Leishman-Donovan bodies whose presence are diagnostic of Kala Azar.The vector of Kala Azar is a sandfly.Leishman-Donovan bodies are amastigotes with a double dot appearance containing a nucleusand small rod-like kinetoplast. They are present inside the macrophage.532

questions.question: A 15-year-old boy from Delhi presented to the OPD with the finding seen in the image. It isdiagnosed to be an oriental sore. Which of the following causes this?515
questions.explanation: The given image shows cutaneous leishmaniasis and is caused by Leishmania tropica complex. Itis also called oriental sore/Delhi boil/Bagdad boil/Aleppo button. It is seen mainly among childrenin endemic areas.Old world Leishmania tropica complex includes 3 species:⚫ L. tropica⚫ L. major⚫ L. aethiopicaNew world Leishmania tropica complex includes 3 species:• L. mexicana complex•⚫ L. braziliensis complexIt begins as a raised papule that grows into a nodule which then ulcerates over someweeks. The margins of the ulcer are raised and indurated. The ulcer is usually painless unlesssecondary bacterial infection occurs.

questions.question: A medicine resident is evaluating a patient with abdominal pain and diarrhoea. The stool wetmount finding is given below. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation: The given image shows the trophozoite form of the Balantidium coli. Living trophozoites/cysts areyellowish or greenish in color on wet mount.•Balantidium coli occurs in two stages:Trophozoites are oval in shape and contain two nuclei. There is the presence of cilia over theentire surface and are larger around the mouth. Its anterior end is narrow and the posterior end isbroad. At the anterior end, there is a groove leading to the mouth (cytostome). Posteriorly, thereis a small anal pore (cytopyge).• Cysts are smaller, round with a micronucleus, a macronucleus and many contractile vacuoles.

questions.question: What is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of kala-azar?
questions.explanation: The rapid dipstick test is the method of choice for the diagnosis of kala-azar.The following tests are used for the laboratory diagnosis of kala-azar:• Rapid diagnostic tests - rK39 and dipstick test strip.• Parasitological diagnosis - demonstration of LD bodies on microscopy is confirmatory•Surveillance purposes - Aldehyde test of Napier533• Serological diagnosis - Rapid dipstick test, direct agglutination test, ELISA, indirect fluorescentantibody test• Assessing immune status - Leishmanin (Montenegro) test• Induration of ≥ 5 mm is considered positive•Usually becomes positive 4-6 weeks after onset of cutaneous leishmaniasis534
